On a city map of Amsterdam this looks a lengthy walk away but isn't at all really and can be accessed by tram.We paid on the door which was 16 euro compared to the 15 euro through Tours and Tickets shops, the price included free roam at your own leisure through the experience, a beer tasting session and 2 tokens for 1/2 pint glasses of beer/soft drinks/water at the end of the tourThe staff seem to rotate stations and ALL were very friendly and helpful.There is a great balance of history behind the beer/brewery and other multi-sensory experiences which were a great laugh, such as the Bottle Me sector and the Media Area. The beer taster was great the beer was only 3 days old and tasted amazing! Soft drinks were available for those not wanting a beer.You can also send a free email picture/video message from the experience and have the option to buy a bottle of Heineken with your own name on it, which is only 5 euros and the bottle is full of beer! The staff were really helpful and understanding when I'd made a mistake with the labelling machine and despite it already being labelled up, staff were happy to alter mine due to the mistake free of charge.Highly recommended

More fun than expected.. After having seen many of the wonderful museums in Amsterdam, we had intended to rent bikes on our last day in Amsterdam, but it rained, so we opted to go to the Heineken Experience instead, and we were not sorry. It was a lot of fun and very informative. One of our group of 4 does not even enjoy drinking beer and she liked to the tour. After the the amusing and entertaining experience of learning about the background of Heineken and the process of making fine beer, we enjoyed drinking the generous glasses of beer and the end of the tour. This tour was not something we had intended to do in Amsterdam, but I would recommend it to anyway who enjoys beer.

Went when it rained. If it rains a worthwhile distraction for a couple of hours inside. A bit of an advertising tour for Heinekin, with a couple of free beers thrown in. There is a part where they need a volunteer don't be afraid to up the beer quota!
A lot of fun!. The most fun I've had on a brewery tour. Not to mention the beer is pretty good too.

Good interactive tour with beer included.... This is well worth a visit. It costs about €15 (including 3 beers!) and takes about 90 minutes. You can walk around at your own pace and can try a few interactive things which are pretty cool.
Must see and do... Nothing more to say than it is worth the money.. A must see ..

So interesting! Very much pleasantly surpised!. When we talked with my husband to visit this Heineken -brewery- Experience, we thought it was another boring have-to-do thing, But when the tour started, we were thrilled! It is everything so well organised and presented in a real interactive way that you feel it is worth it 100%! (Your money and time!) Do not miss it!It would be a good thing if you could pre-buy your tickets to avoid lines. We bought ours, inside the hop-on hop-off bus we used for our overall tour in Amsterdam.

Fun, must do!. Book your tickets in advance and skip the lines - compared with other breweries I have visited (*cough Guinness) you are able to participate much more, and learn more as you go along. The beer 'tasting' was lots of fun, and made you think about what you drank. The personalized beer bottles were a highlight and great memory for 5 Euros.

You might want to like beer first!. It does what it says on the tin. BEER, BEER.... If you have seen a brewery before then you will have seen most of this. But, it does tickle the funny bones at times. The 4D experience is OK. You can record yourself singing Tulips from Amsterdam & others if you want & send it home. We did & found it fun, not to sure if anyone else would, Buy your own beer bottle, €,5 nice memento. Plenty freebies & even tell you how to drink!! Staff weren't too happy when I told them we prefered malt whisky. Buy tickets online, certainly before you enter as it can be very busy. Staff young, some just looked old enough to drink, but very pleasant. Only one complaint to note. Video screen/s of Champions League Cup finals where you picked your favourite moment was out of date & very limited & why no Heineken Cup magic moments? Shop pretty good but slightly dear. Would go back, for the video moment.

Fantastic. I would recommend a vist here. They take you through the process from ingredients to brewing including a bit of fun. Then you have a taster of Heineken before you move on to more of the displays and then 2 free drinks. You can try pulling the perfect pint too which is harder than it looks!!

Best tour for the money in Amsterdam. Amsterdam is so full of many many small tours and museums. In my experience, Heineken gives you the best bang for your buck… and you get free beer at the end! It doesn't get better than that. I have been to other brewery tours in other countries, but no matter how good they have been, none have topped the Heineken Experience. I don't even prefer to drink Heineken, so this is not a biased review. The information about how they make their beer and also about the history of the company was well presented. I also enjoyed watching some of the old commercials. No need to go on and on. If you decide to go, I feel you will be satisfied by the time you exit the Experience.
Not worth it. This was around 20 euro for 2.5 hours of Heineken advertisements and two beers at the end. This IS NOT A BREWERY TOUR by any means!

Miss it out of your itinerary - life will go on.... Quite an average ‘experience’, really. Went in February 2009, amidst mass renovation and street works – the ‘experience’ was fully open at the time, but unfortunately the horses were not ‘home’, because they couldn’t go about their daily delivery business due to the local roadworks (this has now been rectified, and I saw the horses out and about during a later trip).The entrance fee is on the expensive side (15Eur at my last count, with no consolatory discount for the lack of horses), and the tour is entirely self-guided. Whilst this means that you can quite happily wander around at your own pace, it also means that many sections are boring – consisting only of Heineken advertisements throughout the ages, for example.There’s a little ‘ride’ (if it can be called that!) towards the end, where you take a virtual tour of the Heineken bottling/brewing process. Mildly amusing at best. At the very end, you’re treated to up to two ½ pints of Heineken, whilst staff talk some more about the brand. Nice treat, but not really the best environment in which to chill with a beer.We treated ourselves to a commemorative bottle of Heineken on which we printed our own label, which we considered to be reasonably/moderately priced at 5Eur. The Heineken Experience is definitely something you’ll only do once – though you’re not missing out on much if you don’t do it at all!

Interesting but expensive. This is a typical tourist trap....€32 for us to get in and once in then there is more cost if you choose to pay for it...€20 for a t-shirt with your picture on it...€5 for a bottle with your name on it and around the same to get an engraved Heineken glass. These are parts of the tour not just in the shop at the end so you cant avoid them. There are 2 free drinks at the end but all in all if you are pushed for time visit a museum instead!

Enjoyable - even for non-beer drinkers. The Heineken Experience is great value for money. Along the way you get to learn about how beer is actually made and specifically how Heineken is made. The Experience is very interactive. There are many places to pose for photos, beer pouring lessons, a ride and beers included along the way. I don't really drink beer, but surprisingly I had a great time - it was both interesting and fun.I think most adults would thoroughly enjoy this tour.

A must when in Amsterdam. This place is relatively easy to get to, and the experience is one of a kind. I paid 15 euros (Sept 2009) for a pass to enter, two ice cold beer and an experience of a lifetime in a brewery.The tour covers the history of Heineken, how they brew beer in Heineken, how you drink it the Dutch way and lots of display of sponsorship and old ads. It is really a fantastic place to chill, meet fellow travelers and have a cold glass of beer.

Fun place to go but a bit silly all the same.. A shameless advertising venue for Heineken, but if you go without expectations, this is a really fun afternoon out. Wander around some pretty lame exhibition rooms, you'll get a beer halfway during the tour, and then two more in the end, so you'll have a laugh with all the other tourists, who see the silly side of this otherwise pretty pointless venue.

Great value!. A light hearted, fun and interesting tour. A great tour for all ages , especially appealing to people of drinking age , in saying that there was still alot of different activities for kids to take part in and people travelling with children should not be put off taking their kids to the heinekin experience. I highly recommend !

Waste of time and money!. First of all, I'm a non-drinker, so colour my review with that thought. However, even if I were a drinker, this attraction is boring and over-priced. A converted brewery turned into a half-baked shrine to a beer brand doesn't warrant a price of 16 Euros apiece!! Granted you get two free beers and another small glass half way round, but you can buy a six pack for less than eight Euros so why pay more? It certainly wouldn't be to experience the world's worst "ride". The 'Be the Beer' simulator was possibly the most underwhelming attraction I have ever experienced. It's difficult to over-tate how poor it was. I wouldn't even go here to keep out of the rain!!

Much Ado About Nothing. This was very expensive and it consisted of nothing more than rah rah electronics that was nothing more than a few video games, a bunch of old ads and a floor that shakes a little to make you think you are in a brewing pot or being bottled. Glitzy with no substance.

Great fun. Loved our few hours here, very easy to find you just catch the 16 tram. Very interesting museum with loads of interactive things to do like video yourself singing something in dutch which you can email to friends this is so funny. At the end you can either have two drinks or practice pulling your own which we did and thanks to Vincent this was a lot of fun

Cheers!. The Heineken Experience is great! It is informational as well as it is fun. Tickets are 15 Euros, but it absolutely worth it. The staff is always friendly and very entertaining. You will also have the chance to send your family a unique video message, which is really cool. Additionally, you will receive 3 complimentary beers inside (Two at the end of the tour and one as part of the "Heineken Experience"). I would not leave Amsterdam without experiencing Heineken!
DON'T br fooled, Heineken tastes better in Amsterdam. I have been to several breweries for the tour great over-view of how their beer is made, and this one gices you a few beers at the end

Worth your visiting. You will like it - no matter if BEER is your drink or not! I enjoyed every minute of staying their and I am not a big beer favourite. The atmosphere and the effort the creators of this place manage to keep there is definitely worth euro15, which include 2 big drinks free.

If u wanna know beer and then get some.... I went with 3 friends. Fee was 16euro i think to get in. That entitles u to the full entry n self tour AND 2 beer (heineken of course). And if u do not drink, no fret- there are non alcoholic drinks too like soda and juices. You come in and pay the fee. U get a wristband with two buttons clipped on. Thats what u claim ur beer with. Then off u go. I spent about 2 hours in the place cause there is so much to see AND do! U check out how beer is made, the history of heineken animated behind a bar, tons of memorabiloa froms years ago, an interactive room to dj and party away, a room where u can make a music video in dutch, a 4D ride experience of being brewed, a video feedback place and also the videos or mails u compose at the interactive room can be emailed to you. There is also a place where u learn how to taste beer n check out its quality. In the final place of the experience is where u get ur beer and drink up. Nice place to chat with frienda or other travellers. Then there is the souvenier store. I get magnets as always. I suggest not to go in the morning especially if u cant handle ur drinks. Suggest to go at 2 or after lunch n get out around 4 or 5 ao u can grab snacks before dinner.
More than expected ;). It's worth the money you spend for the ticket! Nice atmosphere, friendly staff and great entertainment :)

Great Brewery! Best interactive experience, best brewery I've been to.. This place is great. Complete with a short interactive ride where you see how beer is made. You get a couple of beers afterwards. Fun!!
Best Brewery Tour Ever. Don't miss this! Loads of really cool interactive stuff. Learn the "proper way" to drink a beer.And of course, the beer was great. Bring home a personalized bottle.

Fun fun fun. They rightfully named this...it is an EXPERIENCE. You can easily spend 3 hours here wandering around and learning about not only Heineken but about beer as well. Lots of fun interactive displays here and you get beer at the end!

Had a Great time!!!. This was more that just a walk thru a brewery...we had a great time, also enjoyed the free beers!!! This would be an attraction for young adults to older adults. Wouldn't recommend for children.

Super !!!. Hello all, We "experienced" Heineken on a rainy day in Amsterdam. We were pleaseanly surprised with what we saw and we spent a few hours enjoying everything. The museum takes through the history of the Heineken beer, on the road to see "how it's made" until the end part where you can make a label for your own bottle. I specially liked the part where they "bottled us", although it was a bit different from what I imagined.: ) And also I liked that they tought us how to poor a draght in "Heineken style" and we actually got diplomas for this. :) It's a really nice experience and I reccomend it to everyonr that goes to Amsterdam.

Learn how to prepare beer and drink it!. A visit to Heineken experience is worthy if you have enough time for your stay in Amsterdam.It has ben very interesting to learn about the history of Heineken brewery, to learn how the beer is made and taste it after a brief lesson held by a "beer sommelier". Finally the price it's ok if you consider that you can drink 3 half pints of beer for free.

Great fun. At only 16 euros each for entrance this was great fun. Ignore the overpriced comments! This was cheaper than attractions such as Madame tussards and the dungeons! We spent a few hours going round in our own time; it was interesting and there were lots to do. It was surprising when we noticed a small number of visitors who just walked through some of the rooms not taking part in some of the activities... Take this for what it is and have a little fun. It was a pleasant few hours spent

Brilliant. Excellent attraction - history is put forward in innovative, fun and informative manner. Interactive sections for all age groups. Beer tasting section and just a good laugh! Fun for all even if you are not a beer lover!

Something to do on a rainy afternoon in Amsterdam. Slightly expensive for what you get, but an interesting tour around what was once the Heineken working brewery. Some family history and information on how the beer is made, old ads & bottles, all that kind of thing; plus (of course) some beer tasting included in the price. Best to go in the afternoon and allow time to consume your two free beers at the end. Also includes few inter-active things that make it more attractive for the slightly younger generations. Average - Good (but wouldn't say very good).

Certainly overpriced, but not a bad attraction. I've visited tons of breweries, and this is probably the worst tour I've been on. That's mainly because it only focuses on the extreme basics of beer making, and no beer is even made at this location. This tour focuses mainly on heineken's branding, product placement, and marketing. It was not worth the cost, but I was still able to enjoy myself. For clarification, the cost of the tour includes 1 15cl tasting and two 25ml glasses, and the beer is likely much fresher than what you've had in the past. If you understand that the visit will be expensive and a little corny, you will likely enjoy yourself.

don't bother, do something useful with your time instead. Don't come here, it is expensive, it is basically just an interactive gallery of Heineken advertisements. If you want to learn about beer brewing, read a book on it. Coming here offers nothing. Heineken can be bought anywhere, you don't need to pay for the privelege of coming to a place where you can buy Heineken.And let's be honest, it is a very ordinary beer anyway. Visit nearby Belgium and try some Trappist beers instead. Now that's an 'experience'.

Brilliant Brewery. Being in Amsterdam for only a few nights we decided to try the heineken experience, which turned out to be a great choice. 15 euros to get in, slightly expensive ( like the rest of Amsterdam) however you get your moneys worth. It's interactive, modern and fun, it has character and best part of all you get 2 and a half pints free! Bonus! Defiantly recommend anyone young (18 and over) and old to go while in Amsterdam!

Best brewery tour!. I've done tours of Stella Artois and Staropramen breweries and this is by far the best. Interesting, interactive and great fun. Plus if you have an Iamsterdam card, you get a discount on the entry (11.25 instead of 15 euros each). The fact you get 3 free drinks included is brilliant. Great atmosphere in the bar there as well. Very good.
who knew?. This is well done...fun and informative. Pretty enthusiastic staff people who are friendly and willing to answer any questions. The ride is a little "Disney-esque" but fun.

Beer and fun all rolled into one historical place. This place is extremely fun to go with a friend, learn about a great beer, see their advertising history, several old brewing vats (Heineken is no longer brewed here, but much of the equipment remains for you to play with) and drink a couple of ice cold-freshly brewed beers. At the end of the tour you get 2-free beers; however, during the taste test you get a free beer and if you answer the question(s) right before everybody else, you get another free beer. I walked away with 4-tasty Heinekens in my belly. lol.This place is really big on the visuals and there's a lot of cool activities and/or promtional paraphernalia to keep your mind interested. Also, if your a football (soccer) fan, you know Heineken is a huge sponsor, and because of this there is a room with all kinds of football memorabilia and where you can watch some "Greatest Highlights". We loved this place and I will definitely be back again, when in Amsterdam. I even got a Heineken beer bottle with my name on it. Hint: This is one of the few places that have a great souvenir shop, so bring a little extra money, cause your probably going to find something you want for yourself and/or a friend.

Must try ....you will know a lot more about the beer !!!. Great experience ....didnt realise you could view and experience beer like wine !!!! Its fun ...with the adverts, the horse carraige and the last 2 free drinks !!! Its actually 3 drinks u get free ...1 while tasting and 2 at the end of the tour.You can get your name on the bottle for Euro 5 ...its a great souvenir...

Certainly more of an Experience than a Brewery Tour. This was like no brewery tour I have been to in the past.It is set up extremely well and guides you through the stages a beer will go through (which most breweries tours do), but then you learn how you should drink a beer to get the best tastes, learn how Heineken has evolved over the years, while also having a couple at the end.There are plenty of activities to keep the customer happy and every part of the tour is top notch!Regards,Aussie Assaultwww.flashpackgo.com

I needed more than two Heinekens to get over this Dutch tourist trap. This is an hour-long advertisment for Heineken that you pay €15 for the privilege of watching and mildly participating in.The brewery producing the beer has long since moved, and the building retains much of the original inventory but little of the charm. You walk through a series of rooms all promoting Heineken (when I say promoting I mean heavy advertising). The final room is the bar, much like any bar, but serving only the Dutch master beer.Its one saving grace is the two beers included in the entry price at the end of the 'tour' but I felt as if I deserved more after being robbed of €15.

A fresh and tasty experience for fans...and future fans!. One thing to have in mind: if you're not an Heineken fan (yet)... you'll be there as soon as you feel 'the experience'!The trip around heineken's history is held in a fun and dinamic way, letting you be an active part of the experience... and with always good excuses to have a beer here and there! Ãlong the way you'll feel the brewing process in your skin (!!!), you will get a chance to train your drafting skills and also get a certificate of that...but only if you can make the perfect beer!After a drink (i'm wondering why?) you're invited to be the star in a videoclip, take photos and videos and share them by mail to your friends and family... the end is marked with (another) free beer in their amazing bar: good music, good ambiance with panoramic photos around the world and, of course, a good and cold heineken in your hand!Enjoy the ride!

New Heineken member. yes, well worth your time. imformative, interesting and having a drink as you learn, brilliant. cost is 15 euros and you get a drink durring your tour and 2 more when it ends. now im a new Heineken fan. freshness counts

The longest and most interesting brewery tour I've ever done!. I thought that the price was going to be a bit steep but the tour went on for ages with lots of things I've never seen on a tour like this before. Some of it is very kitchy and some blatant advertising, but honestly you have to expect that! Great tour!

3 beers plus a little movie and learning about brewing. Worth it.. I really liked the bar at the end- it had panorama shots of many great world cities, and it felt like it was night time in there. Would have stayed longer except the tokens ran out ;-)

A must for beer-lovers. It is the old brewery of Heineken family, now transformed into a beer museum. Interesting and educational. Learning how to serve a beer properly and having 2-3 beers, you leave after about 90 minutes happy and satisfied by the Experience. It's fun and worth a visit.
A nice break from conventional museums. It really is a great experience. You get to learn about how Heineken is made. Really cool stuff

If yoy love beer, you´ll love this place!. Just great. A place for beer lovers and anyone interested in how an amsterdam brewery became a world giant. The tour is very good, and you get free beer!! Enjoy

Fun and enjoyable, Easy to find. Went to Heineken Experience Late April, originally planned to go 30/04/2011 good thing we didn't as it was closed this day for the Queens Birthday.Easy to find near Rijks Museum, we walked to it but can get trams out to it. 15 Euros to get in and this gets you 2 free drinks at the end. Not a great indepth look into beer making process but entertaining enough. If it is busy then the ride isnt all that great so wouldn't miss out if you skipped it. Friendly knowledgeable staff. Self guided tour but with small presentations all in English. 2 Free drinks at the end, although you can stand by the doors and ask people leaving if they have spare tokens to prolong the drinking. Took about 1hr 15mins to get around

Slick and inventive interactive experience. I'm not particularly interested in the process of beer making and I feel no brand loyalty to Heineken, so I did question why exactly I was going to this place. I left feeling like a bit of a Heineken convert, so I guess in terms of indoctrination it did its job superbly.It is more than that though, and worth a visit even if like me, you didn't realise you cared how the beer gets in the bottle. There are plenty of interactive exhibits and demonstrations as well as a chill out room where you sit back in the darkness and get bombarded with positive Heineken images to a laid back techno soundtrack. It all ends in a bar where you get to stand and discuss your Heineken "experience" over a few free drinks. You can even record your own appalling music video and have it displayed on the Heineken website.There is masses of merchandise and you can create your own personalised beer bottle for a price.It's all very slick and well presented. I came away feeling slightly empty but I can't deny it was enjoyable on the whole.
Good varied experience. This was a well thought out and well ran thing to do. A bit like willy wongas chocolate factory but with beer. it didn't disappoint.

Fun time. The Heineken Experience was an enjoyable part of our trip to Amsterdam. There was much more to it than I was expecting. Highlights were making your own music video and free beer. I enjoyed it and I don't even really like Heineken.

A nice place to visit. We spent a couple of hourse there few days ago when we were in Amsterdam. Perhaps because we went to the Guinness Warehouse in Dublin last year, we didn't expect something very different. In fact it was slightly less dynamic than Guinness if we really had to compare. We followed the routes and saw the different stages involved in the process. We were taken to "experience" the brewing process by standing on a platform which swings and moves according to different stages. And of course, we got two glasses of free Heineken at the end!We bought a Holland Pass which entitles use to visit seven attractions and we chose Heineken Experience. Otherwise it would be € 15.00.

Coolest tour ever. I enjoyed this from start to finish, the staff was pleasant and I was treated very nicely , I saved my two coins off my bracelet to get a bar tender lesson was so cool , love love loved it :)

Interesting, but don't wait until 5:30 to go in!. We went to this at 5:30...that's the last time they allow people to come in because they close at 7:30. All of the information was well-presented and very interesting. The actual "Heineken Experience" was very cool.The staff, however, was pretty rude. They're almost all young, stoner-type American kids in Amsterdam for the pot (per our cashier Matthew.)At every turn, they were yelling for everyone to leave each section of the tour. The worst part of the experience was the bar where you get your two free drinks. It took forever and it seemed like there were people that had been there drinking all day. The floor obviously hadn't been cleaned all day and the staff was in there yelling for everyone to leave.This made the "Heineken Experience" annoying. I was expecting a more laid-back atmosphere. I'd probably try to go earlier, but beware the long lines. Try to order your tickets in advance.Also, if you buy the IAmsterdam card, you get 25% off...so tickets are only 11.25€.

Much better than I expected!. I went along to this museum to humor my husband, but I am very glad I went. The museum is housed in the former brewery, the huge copper vats and stables are still in place, and the horses still pull the Heineken cart through the streets on a regular basis. Your coats and bags are kept in an old-fashioned cloakroom during your visit, and you receive a taste of fresh beer with tasting tips (yes tasting tips!) part way around. You are brewed (not going to spoil that surprise, you'll have to go to understand). At the end you hand in your free tokens for two free drinks, either a soft drink or... you guessed it... Heineken Extra Cold.

An interesting tour with a fun twist. The Heineken Experience is a great place to visit - so long as you like beer (which fortunately, I do!).The first part is a self guided tour, taking you through the history of the Heineken brewing company, then it's very quickly onto more about the actual beer.From here on, it's very much an interactive tour - there's an introduction and opportunity to taste the constituent elements (trust them on the hops!), freedom to wander round the old copper brewing vats and then onto their "4D Brew You" guide to brewing, which is great fun! You're taught how to pour a perfect glass of Heineken, how to taste, and more about the current/future exploits of the Heineken company. At the end, there's a chance to sit in their lively bar and enjoy your two drinks included in the cost - more Heineken of course!There's also an opportunity to have a personalised bottle printed, as well as glasses engraved in the gift shop at the end.All in all, well worth a visit. I found it very informative and the whole process of brewing was very well explained in an intersting and engaging way.It's €15 for adults, which may sound quite a bit, but that does include two and a half drinks, which are pricey wherever you go.

I've never been bottled...until now. The Heineken Factory was a great break from the usual museums of Amsterdam. Instead of having boring facts shoved onto a plaque on the wall, most of the information was given in an interesting way.We were surprised when we were bottled in the factory...I dont want to give to much away but if you dont know the route inside you will be surprised by a great ride down the factory line.I think i pissed myself laughing afterwards...

Good fun, nice change after Anne Frank and Van Gough. I wasn't expecting too much from this but had seen the good reviews so thought why not! Was really good fun and quite interesting. Took about 2 hours, got 2 drinks in the cost (about 15 euros i think). Quite interactive

Great fun!. For €15 I was expecting something pretty special and I wasn't disappointed. It's a great few hours with friendly involving staff and you can take your time to walk round at your own pace without feeling rushed. The 4D "ride" is awesome, I'm 27 and it made me feel like a little kid! :D I would recommend this to couples of our age and anyone who likes film/tv because a large art of the experience is concerning the advertising and especially their link to the James Bond film franchise. You can also record cool videos and email them to yourself and friends on the day.. not to mention you get 2/3 drinks too!Also free cloakroom and wristband :)

Great experience. Ended up here by accident really as queues for all the museums were huge. I am not a beer drinker however as Brewery tours go this was one of the better ones. Apart from the usual historical stuff and info on brewing process there is also the Brew You experience - a kind off virtual beer making experience. For beer lovers you also get two pints of Heineken. In many ways these are all pretty much an extended advert for their respective product, however it is still an worthwhile trip especially if the weather is a bit off.

Lots of fun!. This was so much fun! You get lots of beer at the end and you can travel the brewery at your own pace (No tour guide, but there are people all along the way if you have any questions). It's great because you can stay at parts as long as you want, or kind of walk past if you aren't interested. I love the end because you can just hang out and talk to other travelers, we met some really nice people and ended up hanging out with them later too.

Great experience. My bf and I visited the heineken experience on valentines day and had a great time! The 15 euros in is a little steep but with this u get ur hands on 2.5 drinks in total! They are quite generous with the booze all in all!We really enjoyed it and you can even order up personalised bottles! Nice touch!

Unforgettable experience!. The Heineken Experience is an interactive, fun, educational, super high tech exhibition that creates such a good feeling that could never be forgoten. We had 2 excellent Heinekens at the end of the visit and I've learned with the bartender how to serve a professional Heineken.

Fun experience. Prepare to start drinking the heineken cool aid. Its a nice pleasant experience - you get to drink 3 beers with your entry.Engage in learning to pour a draught the right way .. fun experience.

Interesting, not boring, much fun and beer. I would like to advice to visit this museum if you like beeer! It;s wonderful museum. You can see take part in different entertaiments! And get 2 bottle - free! Also you can buy bottle with your name on 5 euro.=)) and sitting in the Heiniken bar, whatching advertisment and have nice time with nice people)Netherlands like and proud of thier product and make much to provide it to customers! it's really good experience! Enjoy it!

Cliche, but worth going to. I've toured a lot of different breweries so I was a little hesitant to go becuase I didn't want to be bored. But, it was definitely worth it. Because it's not actually a working brewery, they were able to do some different things that I havent seen at other breweries. They have a "ride' that was pretty neat and enjoyable, and you got to taste different things as the tour progressed (e.g. beer at the different stages of the brewing process). Oh, and you get two free beers at the end of the tour!

Its 15Euro, but it takes about 1.5- 2 hrs to g thru. It was pretty, they have live horses in it , they go thru the brwing anf history, there is sampling and you get to be a bottle of beer (via a simulator machine). Its pretty fun and worth the money. Do it, you will like it.

Very organized, nice and funny!. Heineken Experience is a very nice place to visit, either you´re a beer fan or not... the installation is clean, functional and interesting and you have a lot to do and see there... you´ll find 4D theater, games, history, interactive videos and more. We recommend it!

A really different experience. A good place to visit if you want to know the history of Heineken and for having few pints of beer!! Do not expect this to be a brewery...Its more like a museum and has some interactive moments to keep you awake!! At the end of the visit you get to have 2 glasses of beer which is quite decent enough..For those of you who want a souvenir..try getting your name printed on a Heineken bottle(with beer in it) for 5euros...

Waste of time and money. I have been to a few breweries this one is by far the worst. It is a self guided tour, and every step is all marketing information/pitch. Some of the things they have are ok, but for the money you are better off going to a bar and watching a Heineken commercial.

Not a "must see" but a lot of fun. After spending the day at the Anne Frank House and then the Van Gogh Museum we needed a little bit of fun. We were hesitant to try the Heineken Experience because of the cost and the fact that it we thought that it was just a brewery. We were so surprised to have so much fun. It was very interactive, colorful and fun. We simply had a great time enjoying the advertising posters, the old tv spots, the tours. Nice way to spend a few relaxing hours in Amstrdam.

Well worth the visit!. I have been on a few brewery tours, and this one tops the list. The whole "experience" took about 90 minutes, and was extremely enjoyable.We really enjoyed the 4D ride, as well as seeing the advertising material, the beer pouring video game, and of course the tastings! You can also have a Heineken beer printed with your name on it for another 5 euro, which was a nice souvenir. Had a great time!

nice tour- bur truth in advertisement could improve it. it is indeed a fun tour.the moving and dripping room is a nice add on between drinks, and give you the feel they really want to give you a quality service.for us it was a shame that the attached advertisement wasn't respected ordering a personal bottle at the store- and no body was there to answer us.we even wrote to customer service- again- no response.this is not quality!
Fun Tour. They have what you'd expect and some fun clips of old commercials through the decades. Plus free beer! What's not to like.

Great if you like beer. This attraction is about 15 euros per person and it gives you a great insight into way beer is made. You get a green wristband which enables you two free beers at the end of the experience if you wish or soft drinks if you prefer as well as a free sampler too. There is a 4D theatre which you are part of the process of beer i.e. in the brewing VAT, but wont spoil it for you but its pretty good.You dont realise how good "fresh" Heineken tastes and the best place to taste it is in Amsterdam.

Worth the visit!. Although the museum is a bit pricy, the experience was, undoubtedly, fun. All the attractions are interesting and the “free” beer (with this entrance price, I could not say that those beers were free!) was a nice treat. It was a funny place to take pictures, some of my best shots of Amsterdam was inside this museum. Once we were inside, we were given a Heineken bracelet with three little pins on it, and you could change those pins by beers, at the end of the tour ( you’ll find a large bar and souvenir shop by the end of the visit). But before that, you learn all the manufacturing process and tips on how to take beer off the keg, for example. Another interesting thing is the video recorder: you can record a video clip, singing typical Netherlands' songs (of course you're not really singing, just trying to follow the subtitles on the screen) with a cheesy background, and send it to a friend by e-mail. It is a bit silly, but certainly funny! Worth the visit!

Waste of time really - unless bored or your first opportunity to tour brewery!. I've been on a fair amount of brewery, wine and whiskey tours and this was by far the most disappointing... Maybe it was because we had just come from the House of Bols which I thought was unique and pretty fun, but I just didn't enjoy the Heineken Experience. Its no longer an actual brewery so you don't get that humid hopsy smell of beer brewing. I found the tour long and very tacky with loads of self promotional material. Not really my scene. Would compare it to Cadbury World in Birmingham, only for adults... Sure you get a couple of small beers afterwards, but its not really worth the time and the money unless you are a Heineken nut or you are very bored... Would rather spend the money on a round or two at a nice canalside pub...

Could be in Las Vegas as well....... If you are really interested in the beer making process, like to see a working brewery or are willing to learn facts about beer you are absolutely wrong here!Besides it is at the genuine location this is called the Heineken Experience, not the Heineken brewery. This means it offers you more entertainment than information. Nevertheless, you will be able to see the ingredients before processing, some original copper brew kettles and brewery horses. That’s it with authenticity…..What I really liked was that you are able to taste some mash before fermentation. And the guide will also tell you how to get the maximum taste out of a beer.For your €15 admission fee you will also get three beers, one small (0,15L) at the tasting bar and two regular ones (0,25L) at the bar at the end of the tour. I did like the beer but not the last bar: no windows, crowded, nearly no seating capacities.Gift shop is reasonable priced.

Great time-Worth visit!!!!!!. I visited Amsterdam for the first time the summer of 2010 and i think that this Brewery was one of the most amazing attractions in whole Amsterdam!!!!I highly recommended to visit it!!!!And drink for us also!!!!!!

Most fun I had in Amsterdam. 15 Euros, a great deal for the interesting tour, the movie, 3 beers plus at the end if you make friend with the bar tenders a couple of extra ones from free are not out of the question. Lots of fun and definately recommended.

To be fair I went ten years ago and it.... To be fair I went ten years ago and it was a drink free for all (time limited) so I had some pretty great memories... It has been redone since and is now self directed with a ride and some interactive pieces. You get 2 beers at the end which was lovely! But first you get some serious advert brainwashing! Fun but if you miss it you will live!

Worth it. Some previous reviewers have mentioned that the entry fee was not justified. I believe it was 15 euros and while this was one of the more expensive places we visited, you get 2 1/2 small beers so that's where a lot of the price comes from. Also, any other good quality museum is 8-10 euros entry so the price is justified.And yes, you are bombarded with advertising and branding, but the museum is about around a BRAND! Don't go if you aren't interested. From a branding point of view, I thought it was very interesting (from someone with a background in marketing).There is also a "ride" halfway through, sort of a 3D movie and the platform you stand on moves. It's just silly but still fun.If you are not a beer person, then don't go! I feel like a lot of people show up at this place because it's in their guidebook. It's probably not for everyone but I'd recommend it. And of course it's not a functional brewery, I don't think they advertise it as such.

Not exactly a brewery tour but still a good time. I've been to brewery tours at Anheuser Busch, Coors, and Miller where they give true brewery factory tours. This is not that. In fact, you don't see any of the real brewery operations here. But you do get a history lesson, a bunch of advertising, and a pub like tasting experience. The motion ride you get feels like something they put in place just so they can say they told you how beer is made but is really a waste of time. There are two tasting rooms. The first is expected but then you go to another one that is dark with tvs like a nightclub and you get another 2 glasses.

Such a laugh!. My husband and I went to the Heineken Experience and didnt expect it to be as good as it was! for 15 euro each u get a tour some laughs a video and 2 and a half heinekens! Go here its worth the money!

An Absorbing Brand Experience. I'll admit my perception of the Heineken Experience is a little skewed because I'm in the marketing industry - so experiencing an incredibly richly branded museum like this was more fascinating than anything. I'm not a beer drinker, but my boyfriend's favourite brew is Heineken, so there was no way we were passing this up anyway. What's interesting though, is that despite not being a beer drinker, coming out of the museum made me feel stronger brand loyalty to Heineken. Again, fascinating from that perspective...That being said, there is still plenty to entertain the average person that's a little sick and tired of reading plaques next to paintings. Although there are a number of gallery-type areas featuring facts about Heineken or showcasing the evolution of the brand's image, there are also plenty of interactive elements. You can hop on a 'virtual ride' that moves as you simulate the journey a Heineken bottle takes. There's a gallery that lets you sing hilarious karaoke and take a photo ecard to send to friends and family. Another area showcases a number of modern Heineken branded experiences - including a DJ booth and a drum set made of kegs. Speaking of kegs, you also get to see a simulated brewery, and where the famed Heineken ponies spend their nights (and if you're lucky you'll catch a glimpse of them). The museum ends in a brainwashing room (seriously) where you lie in a comfy chair and cycle through dozens of Heineken ads throughout the years. When I went on the tour a couple of years ago, it was 10-15 euros (honestly can't remember) and you received three half-pints of beer (or a beverage of your choice) and a bottle opener housed in a mock Heineken bottle case - not a bad deal for a couple of hours of entertainment and a break from mundane history.

Definitely not worth it. I'm not a beer drinker but my boyfriend is, and having never been to a brewery before I thought I might as well take the chance to get to learn a bit about beer. If this is what you want too, I expect almost any brewery would be better than this one. It was the second most expensive attraction we visited in Amsterdam (after the zoo) and for what? Firstly a fifteen minute queue - we hardly encountered queues elsewhere. You then amble around the tour at your own pace which doesn't make too much sense with the way things are organised. The first "talk" is actually a video, so that's okay because you can leave when it gets to the part you came in at. But you then receive three talks from guides, who do their best to stay coherent while some visitors pay attention, others stand and chat over them, and others push their way past to the next section. The guides had presumably been instructed to keep things lighthearted so I didn't get to learn about beermaking in the depth I had hoped. Another disappointment was that I had hoped to meet the dray horses but we were offered only a brief glimpse of their stables and no chance to get close.The branding message was a strong one, we were repeatedly told how unique and groundbreaking Heineken was and is, but not specifically why. After the brief history of the brand and the also brief discussion of the brewing method, the rest of the museum was unashamedly just advertising. You can sit in a comfy chair and watch Heineken adverts or scenes from films which feature the brand, in case you have never done this at home. One thing to think about was the fact that everything in the tour was in English. Clearly they do not expect the natives to be gullible enough to visit.You receive tokens to exchange for two 0.2l beers at the end of the tour, plus you get a smaller glass for tasting about half way round, so about a pint in total. Considering you can buy Heineken at more or less any bar around town, you can therefore not use the free drinks to justify the currently €15 entry price.My boyfriend, who likes Heineken as much as he does the next ordinary European lager, is adding it to his "Would rather not drink" list as a consequence of this uninspiring "Experience".

Fun and modern way to spend an afternoon. We bought tickets online, but upon arrival there didn't seem to be any benefit (perhaps we got lucky in our timing). You're guided through Heineken's history and the brewing process. You get to view the original, copper brewing equipment and experience your first sample of "Wort" -- no alcohol yet! You're guided to an optional "ride" which is a short, cheesy, but fun interactive video.A tasting and 2 free beers come with admission. You have the opportunity to send short videos to family/friends with a Heineken Cam for free. For 5 euro you can personalize a bottle of your very own Heineken!Overall, it was an enjoyable experience - but keep in mind that you'll be subject to clever advertising and corporate spin. Take it for what it is - learn about a significant company of Holland and enjoy the beer!
heineken experience- just OK. I was a little dissapointed with the heineken experience. It wasn't even a brewery!

Fun attraction. We went to the van gogh museum just before going to the heineken museum so it was good to go something more light hearted and interesting. The staff were incredibly friendly and welcoming.15 EUR isnt a bad price for the attraction because you get a heineken beer in the tasting room and two in the bar at the end! The attraction is informative starting out with the history of the company then going on to ingredients and how the beer is made we had a talk by a member of staff which was very interesting about what goes into the beer, why they give you small servings and a layer of foam I learnt something! The brew you ride is simple but aimed at younger people, it was funny though. there is a section where you can watch all the adverts through the ages which was good too. The bar section at the end was not too crowded and they have interactive tables which was exciting! There is a lot more things throughout the attraction aswell this is just a brief overview.I would reccomend this attraction if you are looking for something a bit more lighthearted and fun for the afternoon, I would also reccomended if you like heineken too. 15 EUR sounds like a lot, but competitive compared to a lot of the attractions in the area and you can put your coat/bags in their cloackroom for free which is also nice, you can also take photos all the way through the attraction!!

Disappointing. The Heineken Experience is really quite mediocre. The price, 15 Euros, is very excessive for what is on offer. Having to wait 30 minutes in order to watch 6 minutes of a simulation of beer making was irritating. The only positve poibt was two small beers. Shame that they had to be Heineken. Not a place to bother about

A good fun experience.. This is not the most enlightening attraction in Amsterdam, however if you've been to a plethora of galleries and museums it's something a bit more lighthearted. At 15 euros it isn't cheap, but there are 3 small beers thrown in!
Very fun, for the right crowd. Very fun brewery tour, tastings along the way, very informative, fun interactive activities, does cost 15 euros though.

If you are older the ten don't waste your Euro. 15 Euro to suffer through an hour long commercial for Heineken and then two little beers at the end...forget it, go to a nice Amsterdam cafe and have several Heinekens instead. I was so disappointed I wrote a letter requesting my money back. Really it is geared for about a ten year mentality.

Informative and good value - three drinks for 15 euros!. I didn't even know that Heineken was a Dutch beer until I came to Amsterdam, so I had a lot to learn. The Heineken Experience is a pretty informative and interactive set-up, including a Jurassic Park-style explanatory video, complete with water spray and heat lamps to recreate the beer-making process. As part of the 15 euro entry, you get a token for two beers, as well as another one in a part of the tour where you receive useful advice on how to drink a beer. When you consider how much beer costs in the Dam in ordinary bars, this makes the entry cost quite a bargain.
Not what I expected. It really didn't impress me. I would have expected more interaction with people and the process. It would have been nice to see a working operation.
Definitely worth seeing.. Definitely worth seeing if you're into beer and/or the history/process of brewing. The "ride" part is a bit corny, but it's still worth your time.

A fun way to spend a couple of hours in Amsterdam. The Heineken Experience is a fun way to spend some time in Amsterdam. You get to walk through and see how the beer is made and then go on a ride where you actually "go through" the process (you are on a moving platform to enhance the experience). You also get to see the horses, but they are behind a glass wall so you see them from a distance only.Included in your admission price is 2 beers per person. They brand it as a "tasting," so we thought we would try different things, but it's really just a time where the bartender explains more about the beer and pours you a small glass. After this part, you make your way to the bar where you can get the 2 beers. (Non-alcoholic beverages are also available in the bar.) Overall, a well-done experience with lots of high-tech equipment and interactivity. You could definitely spend the good part of an afternoon here while in Amsterdam.

Beautiful old brewery building.. Had a really nice visit to the Heineken experience and would certainly go again if I was taking friends to Amsterdam. The exhibits were interesting and fun and the staff were friendly and cool. The beer was small but cold and very tasty and I was given a bier glass as a souvenir at the end. I've heard that they also give away bottle openers as a gift. I thought that it was good value-I spent about 2 hrs being informed, entertained, given cold beer and finally a souvenir glass at the end.That was 15euro well spent. Oh and yes.. there is a gift shop at the end-I would have been pretty dissapointed if there wasn't one.

Be a Heineken!. The Heineken experience is just a little bit cheesy but it is good fun. The tour guides are intent in you having a good time and the free beer helps get the most out of the experience.

If you are old enough for a mortgage or kids, don't go!. Rip off - it's the Heineken's monument to themselves. They should be embarrassed. It's all about how wonderful they are and what awards they've won for selling us beer. There is short overview on old beer making methods. Then you go thru a silly ride as if you are beer. Then a game room. Then a disco room for chillin from the beer and pot you smoked before the tour. Then you get more free beer (not free, you've paid 15 euros for that beer). Then on to the store to spend money on clothing that advertises for them. They even let you take time to complete a marketing survey to share your ideas. Funny - at home they'd pay me to listen. This tour should be offered with a warning - don't take unless you are stoned.

Great fun. It costs 15 Euros each, but you do get 3 small beers at the end, so that makes it worth the cost. The tour is relaxed, fun and informative. Everything is clean and brightly lit, the staff are polite, very attentive and informative. They also cleverly have a shop at the end after your 3 beers with more branded items than you could ever think of, which I am sure provide an unresistable temptation to a lot of people after a few drinks (including us, we bought my girlfriend a bikini!!). Because of the set up, you can only have 3 drinks, no matter how money you have (unless you want to pay and go through the tour again) so this is not a place full of drunk people which is nice.

Another way for Heineken to make money!!. You pay them to "brainwash" you that their beer is the best. You get 2 free drinks . And on the way out, you can pay more to get their merchandise so that you can advertise to the world for them. These guys are just brilliant!!! I felt like a sucker!

Interesting but biased - Do not go there expecting to drink much beer. Although I am not a beer fan I decided to go there because a friend told me it was interesting even for me.He was right, Heineken people did there quite an effort. It includes a little of everything: the history of the company, how the beer is produced, a tour around the old brewery, horses (!), some digital tricks, football etc. etc. Enough activities to spend some 90 minutes there.There is one problem though. It is the corporate world, so of course all the presentations are about Heineken . Heineken this, Heineken that, the great and charming Freddy Heineken, the beautiful and dynamic Charlene Carvalho Heineken ... It is so excessive that at the end you are willing to curse them. But, as a matter of fact, it couldn't be different. What would you do if you were the Heineken guy preparing a presentation for your company?Anyway, I respect their work and their ideas and give them four stars.The ticket is 15 euros per person. According to my humble opinion, it should be lower. It is funny, but you pay less for Van Gogh Museum which is closeby.And of course, dont go there to get drunk! They offer you only TWO (2) glasses of this divine liquid. Count them: DEUX, DOS, DYO, DUE, ZWEI! Probably rightfully so. Imagine a bunch of drunk guys shouting, annoying and vomiting around. Eeeek, no thanks!

Put this on your list if you have the time!. This tour costs 15e, but you get a green Heineken bracelet with 2 tokens on it that can be exchanged for 2 good size glasses of Heineken beer or 2 soft drinks at the end of the tour. You also get a small glass of beer part way through the self-guided tour. There are 4 levels & 18 attractions. You can star in your own music video & share it instantly with friends at home. You can order your own personalized bottle of Heineken. There is a Heineken Gallery with advertising posters from the past 140 years. There is a stable that is the home of the Heineken Shire Horses. You can tour the historic brew room with its shiny copper vats & learn about the brewing process. There is also a Brew U ride where you can experience what it is like to be brewed & bottled. Funky, but fun! At the end of the tour is The World Bar with panoramic video scenes from around the world...great photography! When I put my beer on the table a virtual coaster appeared & I had fun moving my beer all over the table & having the virtual coaster follow it. The table also had a virtual, interactive map of the world that was fun. Not many stools...most people had to stand.The bartenders were fun & we learned a lot about the history of the Heineken brand and interesting details about the founder. You can shop for everything Heineken on the way out...from clothing to souvenirs.The hours are Mon - Sun 11:00 - 19:00. We did not have to wait in line long to get in.
fun and free beer. fun place - hi techy experience and interesting and free ice cold heineken
Fun way to spend a couple of hours. The Heineken experience exceeded our expectations. It was part education, part ride, part bar.

Nice interactive place. We were given a free 'whats on in Amsterdam' magazine on arrival at our hotel which had in it a page with 20% discount on entry so look out for those! We got there at about 11am ish and it was pretty quiet. We certainly didn't feel cramped and the motion ride thing (where you are the bottle) had no queue - we walked straight in. Its a good interractive place, we made out own video singing 'tulips of Amsterdam' in Dutch (karaoke) that we could then email to ourselves.. and able to download once we got home. Drank beer, tasted beer and tasted the beer process (before yeast etc) It is just one big advert for Heinken I suppose but it was interesting and we certainly spent about 2 hours in there in total and wasn't bored at all. The room at the end was quite relaxing (where you get to have two extra cold glasses of beer) so we probably sat in there for about half an hour. My only complaint would be that I would have liked to get more up close to the beautiful horses.. not even to touch them but we could only see a tail swish and smell them... ha ha but from what we saw they looked like magnificent creatures.

Not worth the €15 entrance. I went to the Heineken experience with my boyfriend on a rainy Sat afternoon in July '09. I arranged for us to go thinking that it would be the kind of museum he'd enjoy. We thought it would be fun to learn more about beer brewing and the history of Heineken and did expect the experience to be very Heineken-focused and biased, so really didn’t have the highest expectations. Still we were both a bit disappointed with the whole experience, it was OK – nothing more.It’s well thought out, it's fun and interesting enough, staff is really friendly, but it really isn’t worth the €15 entrance. The place is just one big celebration of Heineken, their products, the company, the founder etc. It's just too much to have to read: "The founder of Heineken, always thinking about his employees first, arranged an early pension scheme during economic crisis in 19XX, so he didn’t have to lay off employees”. How very nice of him, he was such a good man, but at that point you start feeling a bit nauseated (and you haven't even tasted the beer yet).Our problem wasn’t really the poor value for money. The entrance fee was too high - yes - even with the three tiny beers included (and we didn’t receive a free gift as someone mentioned in their review, I think they’ve scrapped that bit). It’s was more the principle that you really shouldn't pay to be exposed to one long Heineken promotion - which in essence is what this place is. It should be free or at least very inexpensive, as the value of having my attention (as consumer) focused on one brand for 1-2 hours is priceless for Heineken. Hey... they should be paying me! Had they added more information on beer brewing in general, how the yeast creates carbon dioxide etc. and showed how the beer is brewed (as they did earlier), it would become a more balanced experience that I'd be willing to pay for. They do mention the process briefly, but it is too superficial. It is not closed for renovation anymore, as it says here on Tripadvisor.

The Guiness brewery was so much better!. Having been to Amsterdam a few times, we finally found the time to get to the Heineken Experience. I initially thought the price of 15 euros was a bit steep, but thought maybe I'll be surprised. After checking our coats in (in July no less!), we had our tickets scanned and started our tour. Our first impression was 'man is this place cramped!' We barely had room to read the information and history of the brewery, let alone take a picture without being bumped. There wasn't much to see anyway. We then waited in line for 15 minutes for a ridiculous motion ride. I don't even know why they bothered with this. We were only laughing at how stupid it was. We were then ushered into a room with a couple of annoying bartenders to serve us a beer, which we had to admire and smell before we could drink. After this, we went to the last bit, where we had another glass of beer. This place was overly crowded, and there was nowhere to sit, and barely room to stand. I think the only part we liked were the prices of the souvenirs at the end, and the personalized bottle of Heineken. The Irish definitely did this better!

Well Worth the 15 Euros. Very amusing place, with a great 4D ride. Price includes 3 beers and cloak room.Well worth the 15 euros spent, and prepare to spend a leisurely 90 mins here.Personalise your own Heineken bottle or glass here!

enlightening experience. having drunk beer for years now and a big Heineken fan, it was good to see how it was all brewed, the ingredients and of course the free drinks! a must-go for all heineken fans

beery good fun!. This is a really well done, interactive, experience The video potted history of Heineken is nicely done, looking like the guy is behind a bar. You can see the original old big copper kettles where the malting was done, then taste the hops and barley before they get brewed. There's a nice tasting bar, some interactive funky bits, a fussball table and some euro footy trophies. Some of this is a bit heavy on the Heineken marketing but generally its well done. There's a 3-d cinema type thing which simluates you going through the brewing process! Then another bar. TIP - when you've used up your last token, if there's a friendly bartender, ask if you can try out what you learned in the tasting room and have a go at pulling a pint. Even if you get it wrong you prob get to drink it!!

Crowded, but worth the visit.. My husband, the avid beer-drinker that he is, and I stopped to take this tour first thing upon arriving in Amsterdam. When you first start the tour (it's self-paced, thank God) it's really packed because there's a lot of people trying to maneuver through a small hall and a few small rooms that have pictures and history in them (nothing like the Guinness tour in Dublin). Once we were able to break free from the crowd though, it was great! There's a lot of information and hands-on things to do and try, plus a lot of great picture opportunities if you're a photo geek like I am. We got two full sized samples at the end of the tour and a mini sample somewhere in the middle. The gift shop is full of anything and everything Heineken and we got a free bottle opener because we filled out a survey at the end. Well worth the visit!

Enteraining if you have extra time. This self-guided tour requires you be a beer lover and in the right mind-set. Fun to see various steps in brewing, old logos and ad campaigns and learn about history of the beer. The highlight is the bottling experience ride and the 2 sample beers.

Fun, Interactive, a great time!. As a non-beer drinker I only went here to keep my Other Half happy, having dragged him to 3 museums at this stage, so I wasnt expecting much... It was excellent, really good fun, informative too. You can see how the beer was brewed, taste some of it straight from the barrels (beware its warm!!) and you get two free (half) pints. There is a eally great atmosphere in the place, definatley go on the Brew You Ride, it sounds stupid, as they promise to turn you into a bottle of Heineken, but I defy anybody not to come out of this with face-ache from laughing! For the sports enthusiast dont miss out on the room dedicated to all things Champions League related.

Reaches the parts other Brewery's can't reach!. Recently spent a lads weekend in Amsterdam for the Holland v Scotland football international. We thought we would spend a leisurely Sunday at the Heineken Brewery Experience and I am so glad we did - It was excellent!Started off a bit dull, but then you go into a theatre show with a moving floor where you are the beer. Then it's on to the interactive room where you can record a message to email to a loved one and also enjoy a sing along and email to friends too.The last part of the journey is in the bar area which is very modern and even has virtual beer mats on the electronic tabletop. The tables also have a laser beam show running the whole time, the theme being cities of the world.Cost 15 euros, which considering you get 3 free beers too, is not at all bad and I would recommend you take the time to visit this attraction when in Amsterdam.
So much better than expected. If you have any interest in beer and its production, give this a go. I expected it to be some kind of Disneyworld of Beer, but it's so much better than that.

A lot of fun--if you're a tourist be a tourist and go. When visiting Amsterdam in January 2009, my partner and I stopped at the newly refurbished Heineken Experience as part of making the tourist rounds. If you accept the fact that it's designed primarily for tourists we really had a good time. The attractions were clever, (see how the beer is made, taste the wort, interactive movie presentation) and they were not stingy on the samples! One small glass in the first tasting room and two larger glasses at the bar at the end. Note: being there in winter with fewer people was very pleasant--high summer with the teeming masses might detract a little from the leisurely pace of the tour.

Fun. Fun place... somewhat a bit cheesy but fun nonetheless. The ending is a bar atmosphere and everyone was super cool there. Definitely check it out if you have time and like beer. I'll be going back again for the second time.

fantastic. visited the Heineken Experience not long after it re-opened after its renovation.cost only 10 euro to go in & well worth the money.Loads of stuff to see & do inside & 2 beers included in the price.well worth a look if you are in Amsterdam

An advert you pay for!. As we went soon after the Experience re-opened we paid only 10 euros per person, if we had paid the full price of 15 euros we would have been very disappointed. As it was it was mildly annoying and we left feelign that the Heineken Experience was more like an advert you have to pay to see than anything else! The staff are pleasant and take your coat and ushure you in to the H.E. You first watch a video about Heineken and have a photo oppotunity with some old style adverts (which was one of the best bits!)You then go through a brief history of the beer and brand, which consists of reading and occasional old bottles and the like. You can then see the brewing process and taste pure hops.Then you 'become a bottle of Heineken', by standing on a juddering platform and watching a odd video featuring a English bloke. Even though the H.E. only just re-opened one of the platforms was already broken!Then you get a mini beer to drink and go in to a weird room of 'pop videos' you can 'star' in. Then there is a room of music and visuals of nothing much, chairs where you can watch decades of Heineken adverts and posters. Finally you get a half of Heiniken in a room with about three seats.Over all we felt this was a bit of a waste of time and money, you hardly know anything more about the beer or brewing after it and it all really feels like they are selling Heineken to you throughtout and nothing much more.

Still not open. We were very disappointed to turn up to the Heineken Experience only to find out that it is still closed for renovations. Apparently it is supposed to be open 'this summer' but with summer upon us it is still not open. We spoke to a staff member inside the Heineken building who said that he thinks it may be open by September 2008, but he gave the vibe that it may even not happen by then. This is obviously something that has gone way beyond the anticipated timeline, but to the disappointment of many tourists I'm sure. It's still something on my list to do because I've heard that it is great, but it will have to wait until my next (if ever) visit to Amsterdam.
beer is good. Well worth the admission price. Three beers and a beer opener. And all the interactive displays and games were a blast!

A definite Must See in Amsterdam. I gave it an excellent for 4 reasons:1. Very reasonable entry rate and free coat check, I tipped the staff.2. You get 3 beers throughout your tour. Not all at once. The freshest Heineken I have ever tasted.3. You get a cool souvenir at the end of your self guided tour. We got salt and pepper shakers, but we have heard they vary, all depending on when you go, I guess.4. Staff is extremely friendly.I am not a beer drinker at all but this place was highly recommended. I am happy we were able to go here.

A place worth your time in a city with a lot to see. This was a fun time, simply put. For just over 20 euros, my wife and I visited the brewery to learn about Heineken. I expected a small tour, a little taste and then to be shuffled out the door. Not so. There is a self guided tour that goes over the history of the beer. Old posters. You visit the brewing kettle room, those things are massive. In the middle is a quaint bar where you can get a sample (you get three samples each with your entry fee). After that, they have some interactive areas. Take the time to make a video and send it to your friends - lots of fun. There is also a strange room with pod type beds where you can lay down and look at old commercials - fun as well. Overall, a great time. We actually took the time to visit the gift shop and speak to some of the employees. The ones that we spoke to said it was a great place to work and they had lots of fun. They seemed proud of their company and wanted us to know it. A refreshing change from some of the other tour spots we have visited.

Excellent value for money and great fun!. For 11 euros you get 3 beers and a really nice souvenir which I think is excellent value for money (considering the price of beer in the bars of Amsterdam!). Also you get to have a fun and interesting tour around the old Heineken brewery and learn some interesting facts along the way.I went with a group of 5 friends and we spent a very enjoyable 2hours here. The interactive shows are hilarious, the brewery itself is spotless and the bar areas are really funky! There is also an area where you can mix your own tunes on a DJ desk which was good fun and the chillout zone was very relaxing.There is also an area to email photos and video messages to your friends and family which is a nice interactive momento of your visit.Would give this 10/10 and would gladly do it again!

Fun, worth doing.. We spent our first afternoon here. It took about 11/2 hours to complete. Was fun and by the end of the tour I was happy as you get 3 free drinks (think it only works out about 3/4 of pint, but still). You also get a free gift which is a bottle opener.Was 11 euros to get in.

Heineken Experience......One fun time.. We were recently in Amsterdam, and took the Heineken experience, which is a visit to a "Museum" in an old Heineken brewery. It is clearly set up as a display for Heineken promotion, but is so well designed that one doesn't mind paying to go to their commercial.When you enter, you are exposed to recreated streets and shops where you might be expected to drink their beer. It is very well put together.As you progress, you are invited into a tiny theater. When you enter, you find a small room with metal bars to lean against, not expecting anything but a commercial film, but when the film starts, the floor starts moving, and you are subjected to what it must feel like to be a bottle and moving through the bottling process at the brewery. It is so cleverly put together with the floor moving in all directions as the bottle moves down the line, that it becomes a fun experience.From the movie, you proceed through a number of displays. They are in a spotless environment with huge polished copper vats, and you are free to wander. After you leave this area, you enter an area where friendly bartenders give you a beer or soft drink.Pushing on, you go through more exhibits, including a surreal area where you can watch Heineken commercials. Eventually you wind up in another place where you can have two more beers or soft drinks. The bartenders are just as congenial at this gathering hole.Of course you have the opportunity to purchase Heineken things like shirts or glasses and other items. When you leave, each person receives a nice bottle opener as a souvenir.The Heineken experience is a fun time for adults and when you consider the price of everything else in the Netherlands, it is a real bargain.

Beer for breakfast. This is in the original brewery that is no longer in operation. It takes you through the history or the heineken and is not bad though not that great either. We went early as we had seen a line up in the afternoon the day before, there was no line when we got there so that was good. Included with your entry will be tokens for 3 beers throughout your tour, so if you go early in the morning, you will be enjoying a beer breakfast!

Excellent Experience!!!. We were looking for Van Gogh Museum and then we found heineken experience... running because we were just in time, but really nice place, a lot of facts and history and delicious beer for degustation...

Great value, and a fun place to visit. We thought this was very good value indeed. For 11 Euros each, the attraction also includes drinks and a souvenir gift. On entry you get four different coloured tokens that you exchange as you go round.The first part of the self-paced tour takes you through the rooms of the old factory, and introduces you to the Heineken family, and the process of brewing. Information was presented in English, as well as other languages.There is an amusing attraction half way round in which you go into a smallish room with a screen, and you get to feel what it is like being a bottle on the conveyor belt. It made us chuckle.Shortly after this, there is a mid-way bar where you exchange one token for a drink of Heineken – there was also Pepsi, Fizzy Orange or water for non-beer drinkers.Towards the end of the experience, there are a few other stand-alone attractions. One seemed to be a small simulator ride where you were driving a horse-drawn carriage through the streets. Another was something curious with music and a DJ, and a third had people lying on space-age style seats looking up at screens. Unfortunately, we didn’t try any of these final things, since the queues were building up (or, in the case of the DJ thing, we didn’t understand what was meant to happen, and were a bit wary of getting involved with something that might embarrass us!).The end of the tour leads you to the gift shop, and the final bar where you can exchange two tokens for drinks, and then back to the entrance foyer where your last token is exchanged for a nice souvenir gift.We were probably in here for 70 minutes, or so, but could have stayed longer if we experienced the three separate attractions towards the end. We would have liked to have seen the Heineken horses up closer – the only time you see them is through a window, looking down on their stable – but this aside, we recommend this as a good value, fun visit.

What a surprise !!. Coming here was a last minute decision on our third day in Amsterdam. Was here with my 2 daughters in July 2007, and we had an absolute blast !! Lots of interesting stuff - lots of interactive things to see and do. Getting 3 big glasses of beer each was indeed a surprise - cost was 11 Euros for the self-guided tour, three beer and a souvenir. Note: When you arrive, watch the people who have finished the tour !! It's hilarious - they're all quite HAPPY !!!!!

Heineken Experience - An Awesome Experience. If I was only allowed to recommend one attraction in Amsterdam, this would be it! Both me and my boyfriend loved it there!LOCATION: It is a bit out of the main part of Amsterdam, situated in Heinekenplein. You could walk there, but it could take a while - we just took the tram from Centraal Station (Tram 16, 24 or 25) to Heinekenplein - you can't miss when to get off, just stand on the left side of the tram and you'll see a large building marked HEINEKEN BROUERY. OPENING: June, July and August: Mondays through Sundays, 11.00 - 19.00 hrs. Last ticket sales: 17.45 hrs. September, October: Tuesdays through Sundays, 10.00 - 18.00 hrs. Last ticket Sales: 17.00hrs.COST: 11E to get in - and we think it's well worth it, as you get 3 tokens each for 3 drinks at the 2 bars there - they're Amsterdam sized drinks so hey, they're free! If you don't drink beer there's soft drinks available too. You get a free gift at the exit - but I won't spoil the suprise. We were pretty pleased with ours. MUSEUM: The first part is all about the history of the beer and what goes into making it, and so forth - this was quite interesting, but not the most interesting. You can enter a room where they used to make the beer, as well as numerous other attractions such as assuming the role of a Heineken bottle which is quite fun, a virtual ride on the Heineken Horses, you can 'DJ', and various other interactive bits - even a bout of karaoke where you appear in your own video, and it was fun watching other people do it. We loved these bits! You can send emails home to your friends, video messages, make them jealous that you're in Amsterdam and they're not!You tour the museum yourself at your own pace, as fast or slow as you like. We went quite early in the day and there were no crowds at all. We spent about 2 hours here I think, doing the tour, the interactives, the bars and then the gift shop. The gift shop at the end is great and quite cheap so we were suprised. 5E for a massive Heineken glass tankard - bargain!! VALUE: 5/5HEADLINER?: 4/5 - It should be!FUN FACTOR: 5/5OVERALL: 5/5WOULD WE RETURN? Do we like beer and free stuff? (The answer is yes!)Have a look at my photos and see for yourself!

Excellent beer tour. Heineken gives an excellent tour. The 10 Euro entry fee includes three beers. Everything is professional. Most of the tour is informative with the history behind Heineken. Some is interactive, with games or the chance to email your photo to a friend from the brewery. The tour is self guided and at your own pace. There are some stairs. This tour is a good time and fairly good value. Plan about 2 hours. The only problems were that some of the interactive machines seemed to be malfunctioning, and the only beer available is the lager, even though Heineken brews dozens of brands in The Netherlands.
