The gift at the end was a bottle opener.

What a Refreshing Change. This is a must if your a drinker or not, even young children are allowed in to this truely brilliant experiance.Once youve paid your 10,00 euro to get in you get beer tokens and a guide, theres a sovenier shop and a few bars, the museum tells you how the bier is made at the Heineken brewery and also up to date simulators to ride on. I have now been twice with my girlfriend and we both enjoyed it lots, well worth the money and next time we`re in Dam we`ll be going back.

Worth a visit. Some have said this is one long beer advert and in a way it is but the fact that its called the 'Heineken' experience means you should expect some promotion!! My girlfriend and i really enjoyed the tour, you can make your way around at your own pace and get to stop a couple of times for beers which you 'pay' for with tokens you are given when you buy your tickets. The 'being a bottle' ride is fun, the horse and cart ride is a little cheesy but overall this attraction is well worth a visit.
A ten Euro beer comerical. What a waste of time! With all to see this in this wonderful town, put this on the bottom of your list! It is a self promoting beer commerical.

Fun for all. We went as a family w/ 2 teenagers. It was treat for all. We had a great time and it was well worth the 10 Euro price. My 16 and 13 year old had a blast and so did we. After all the paintings in the museums and Anne Franks house, we needed someting light and fun! This was it. Our videos were waiting for us when we got home and that made it even more fun!

Boozy Brilliance!. This is a brilliant attraction and a must when in Amsterdam. An interactive and exciting experience, you are infored as to the history of the company and its brewing methods. As it is housed in the old brewery, used until 1989, you actually wander about in the various tubes, tunnels and vats used for making the beer. And you get 3 free beers and a bottle opener along the way, too!

Superb, fun and value for money!. We expected to spend an hour at the Heineken experience but ended up spending two and a half hours there! we arrived at 10am and were the first few in. As we were paying we made the H sign as mentioned below, as well as the 3 free drinks that you get with your entrance fee you also get a special free Long Neck bottle of Heineken that has Amsterdam on the label! Make sure you do this, we felt a little silly at first but the lady laughed and seemed very pleased that we had done this, she brought our vouchers.The place itself explains Heinekens history and brewing processes well through multimedia and interactive things. Some are fun, some are interesting. Their is plenty to see and do. Even a couple of 'rides' that show the life of a bottle of beer and one on a hors and cart ride through the city! Plenty to see and do. The first bar you get a half which is incredibly refreshing and nice and cold. Their is a shop with plenty of gifts available for decent prices and noce are tacky. The place has a definite advertising aim but who cares?! Its fun and free beer! You finish in a nice bar where you recieve two more small beers and the Long Neck if you made the H sign with your hand. We spent nearly an hour in here, beside the seats their is an interactive map on the wall that has touch screen technology showing the sites and attractions in Amsterdam. You then move on and recieve your free gift which originally a glass in a presentation box but has now been replaced by a Heineken bottle made of tin that opens in half revealing a bottle opener! Cool!Overall, we had a fantastic time and will return. You can't beat paying 10 euros and recieving 4 free drinks, a free gift and as much time as you wish in a museum! Superb!

Not the state museum, but worth the time. I visited the tour in late March 2006. It was nice to get out of the light snow falling. Last time I had visited the tour was almost 20 years earlier. At that time they took you to a real production brewry. At the end, you could drink plenty of beer, and the tour was free. This now seemed a bit too much like Disneyland.If you figure what the beers cost at a pub or restaurant, plus the free glass provided in the tin at the end, I would say it has value at least equal to the 10 Euros the tour cost.If one really wants to visit a brewry tour- go to Pilzen in the Czech Rep. and watch them make Pilzner Urquell.

Experience the experience. We decided to visit the Heineken Experience (click here to find out more about the ins and outs -heinekenexperience after a work colleague of mine told me about it. It is the old brewery house in Amsterdam of the famous Heineken lager. They had gone the month before us and had really enjoyed it, plus they told us if we made this sign with our hands at the cloakroom before you went in you would get ‘special’ beers at the end of the trip (during the tour you get 3 free beers) called Longnecks.So off we went. Did feel a little bit silly making the sign but the lady behind the counter just smiled and got a couple of passes out and stamped them. I have loaded up a couple of pictures so you can see what you need to do.The ‘experience’ is great, loads of interactive features, and well laid out, lots of staff on hand to ask questions of. We went on a Saturday and even though there appeared to be lots of people there it didn’t feel crowed or cramped.As you get to the end of your trip you come into a large modern looking bar where people are drinking their ‘free’ beers which you get with your entrance ticket, here handover the pass you had stamped as you came in and you will receive the ‘longneck’ bottled beer rather than the small glass everyone else is drinking.Even without the ‘special’ beer at the end of the Heineken Experience I would recommend anyone visiting Amsterdam to take some time out and go and visit. It is really worthwhile and if you remember to make the ‘h sign’ with your hand when you go in you will get the Longnecks rather than the small tap glasses. Enjoy!

Worth the €10 entrance fee. A short walk from the centre of Amsterdam, this visitor attraction was worth every penny of the €10 entrance. I would arrive, if possible, before 11am to avoid the big queues. After paying, you are issued with 4 coloured tokens and a numbered guide. You enter the attraction and follow the signs and numbered items along the way. After a while you come across the 'bottle ride' which is a small platform for 20 ish people where you face a large screen and you are jigged around on the platform while a video of the bottle line plays, the idea being you feel like a Heineken bottle on its journey to being filled (fun). After this you move to the first bar where you can have you can have your first beer. After this bar you continue to the next section and a further ride that takes the form of a beer delivery dray where you sit in 4 seater replica traps and watch a video of horses delivering beer around Amsterdam, again being jigged around (also fun). Next stop is the final bar area and shop. 2 beers are served here. When you exit the attraction the final token is exchanged for a 'gift' which is a nicely packed 250ml Heineken glass as a souvenir.....VFM (value for money).If you would also like to see the canals of Amsterdam after a visit here, it might be wise to book with the cruise company across the road from the Heineken Brewery as they are far less busy than the mor centrally located companies, and you see exactly the same canals on a 1-1 1/4 hr tour.

A fun way to pass a couple of hours. Rembrandt this ain't. The Heineken Experience is good fun, and probably a welcome break from solemn museums and art galleries. It's a fun way of learning more about beer, and the Heinken history. The bottle ride is a hoot, and the free beers along the way make the trip even more fun (I like beer as you can probably tell). Not the most high-brow thing you'll see or do while in Amsterdam, but probably the most fun, and not bad value at €10.

A Must for Beer Fans. The Heineken Experience is a dream come true for Heineken fans (like myself) or for other beer drinkers. Included in the reasonably priced admission you get a self guided tour of the brewery, with lots of exhibits to explore about the history of Heineken and the making of Heineken plus other fun (and sometimes hokey) rides that show what it's like to be a bottle of Heineken, or to ride in a horse drawn delivery carriage. Best of all there are several stations along the way where you can cash in the three free beer (or soft drink) tickets that came with admission. This is even better if you're traveling with someone who doesn't drink beer. There's also a gift shop full of lots of unique Heineken gear. And as if that's not enough you get a free gift at the end of the tour which is a Heineken tin containing a souvenir Heineken Experience Beer glass. Nice!A very fun way to spend a few hours.

A fun travel break. We have been to Amsterdam many times. On our way to Italy, we had a lengthy layover at Schiphol, too long to stay at the airport but we didn't want to do anything that required alot of thoughtful observation - we were functioning on a 6 hour time difference and trying to stay awake until our 9 p.m. arrival in Milan.We trained into the city and had an early lunch on Dam Square. Then walked to the Heineken Experience. Had great fun, enjoyed the exhibit, the music mix, the fresh beers, the virtual bottling plant and the horse ride through Amsterdam streets. It's not Disney (that's good) but well done. Not terribly intellectual but it is educational. All in all, 10 E well spent. The gift at the end is nice - don't forget to claim it My favorite thing - the stairway made of bottle glass.

Its OK. I found the experience not to be that big of a deal. I didn't learn much and the video that we made never made it to the email addresses we typed in. Its silly and cheap. But if you like beer, I suppose its good times. I didn't and my travelling partener enjoyed twice the beer she should have. By the end of the tour, it was the best place she's ever been. The glass they give you at the end of the tour is pretty nice.
A Must see. ride the shire horses. Experience what its like to be a bottle.. Best tour in Amsterdam. Audience participation is great. Riding the shire horse and buggy. Halograms are great.

Well Worth Doing - Even if your not a beer drinker!. Having just spent a few days in Amsterdam, this was one of the highlights. Didn't get to do many of the other museums so can't compare it with those in Amsterdam, but by far one of the best 'museums' I've been in in a long time. For 10euros, you can go a very entertaining self guided tour - with fun rides, and interactive things to do - and you also get 3 half pints and a souvenir glass included! Not bad! If you've got the time, definatley recommend making the effort to visit, even if your not a drinker.

Well worth the few bucks - Also a cheap morning buzz. Being a beer advocate and dedicated beer connoisseur I really enjoyed this tour. Very informative about how the beer is made down to their patented strain of yeast. the people were friendly and answered all your questions.At eh time I went there was only 2 tours a day and only a limited number of people per tour. It took us two tries to get on it. I recommend getting there early - about 1 hour before the tour starts. There was a cafe across the street where you could watch for the line to start forming and have a cup of coffee. At the end of the tour they give you all the Heineken you can drink. Considering this is about 9 or 10 in the morning - you have to be a dedicated drinker. Afterwards you can cross the bridge back towards Leidsplein and there will be a Carousel Pancake house - AWSOME Bacon Pancakes. They do Bacon and pancakes different than in America. They cook a couple of strips of bacon and then pour about an 18 inch wide pancake on top of the bacon slices. After getting that early morning buzz the pancakes were excellent.
